title-group.article-title: Toward a Taxonomy Linking Game Attributes to Learning
title-group.subtitle: An Empirical Study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, University of Central Florida, Orlando, USA
2Institute for Simulation & Training, University of Central Florida, Orlando, USA

author-notes.corresp: Eduardo Salas, Institute for Simulation & Training, University of Central Florida, 3100 Technology Parkway, Orlando, FL 32826, USA Email: esalas@ist.ucf.edu

abstract.p: The serious games community is moving toward research focusing on direct comparisons between learning outcomes of serious games and those of more traditional training methods. Such comparisons are difficult, however, due to the lack of a consistent taxonomy of game attributes for serious games. Without a clear understanding of what truly constitutes a game, scientific inquiry will continue to reveal inconsistent findings, making it hard to provide practitioners with guidance as to the most important attribute(s) for desired training outcomes. This article presents a game attribute taxonomy derived from a comprehensive literature review and subsequent card sorts performed by subject matter experts (SMEs). The categories of serious game attributes that emerged represent the shared mental models of game SMEs and serve to provide a comprehensive collection of game attributes. In order to guide future serious games research, the existing literature base is organized around the framework of this taxonomy.

body.p: Although the study of games as learning tools has benefited from intensive research efforts since the 1980s (e.g., Malone, 1981), the theoretical base of serious games is still largely nascent. A major problem hampering this line of research is the lack of consensus regarding what elements constitute a game (Klabbers, 2009). Sid Meier claims that “a [good] game is a series of interesting choices” (Rollings & Morris, 2000, p. 38). However, a game is more than a set of choices; numerous researchers have attempted to definitively organize game attributes that constitute a true “game.” The early work of Malone and colleagues (Malone, 1981; Malone & Lepper, 1987) argued that attributes such as challenge, curiosity, control, and fantasy constituted the core of a game. Later works have expanded this view to incorporate defining elements such as the task nature, roles of the player, presence of multiple methods to achieve goals, the level of player control (Gredler, 1996), conflict, control, closure, contrivance (Thiagarajan, 1999), and even goals, rules, constraints, competition, and specific game contexts (Leemkuil, de Jong, & Ootes, 2000). Recent efforts have focused on similar attributes (e.g., rules), but also include quantifiable outcomes, the player’s effort level, player attachment to the game outcome, and negotiable consequences (Juul, 2003). Still others have focused on a more parsimonious view of essential game elements, suggesting that challenge and risk are the most crucial attributes (Baranauskas, Neto, & Borges, 1999).

Clearly, many attempts have been made at defining what constitutes games in order to understand how they work to engender learning (e.g., why they are engaging, how they convey knowledge, etc.). However, these efforts lack unity in their approach, resulting in findings that are difficult to integrate. Overlap almost certainly exists between these various games, as in the case of rules and goals. Reconciling evidence for overlapping constructs provides a theoretical challenge, requiring a more parsimonious, orthogonal taxonomy. Yet, despite the growing research interest in serious games, a unified taxonomy remains elusive.

The use of serious games is progressing without explicit knowledge as to why games are effective teaching tools. It is not clear which attributes lead to which learning outcomes. Without an accurate understanding of the root factors influencing the effectiveness of serious games, these training tools cannot be harnessed to their fullest potential. In order to move the field forward, the serious games community must build a basic-science understanding of serious games. On the lowest level, this requires research on the effects of individual game attributes and features on learning outcomes. Examinations of game attributes will provide evidence for determining what exactly makes a game appropriate for learning (Clark, 2007). The lack of distinction between the various previously identified attributes complicates such research. A universal taxonomy of game attributes would provide a common language and starting point for researchers examining the effects of these attributes.

We have seen recent developments in this direction (e.g., Garris & Ahlers, 2001; Wilson et al., 2009); yet, in terms of research usefulness, these efforts are either lacking in comprehensiveness or have issues with construct overlap. This is not to criticize those works, but rather to suggest that they were necessary foundational efforts, which must be built on in order to move the field forward with systematic empirical evaluation. In order to define attributes of a game in a way that can specifically guide future research, more discrete definitions are required. This work builds on Wilson et al.’s (2009) game attribute matrix by using card sort responses from subject matter experts (SMEs) to create a parsimonious taxonomy of game attributes. The taxonomy and its implications for research are addressed in three sections. First, detailed discussion will center on the problem of previous taxonomic efforts by introducing the initial set of attributes used in the study. Then, the specific sort methodology used to create the parsimonious taxonomy will be discussed. The article ends with a summary of results and implications of the sort alongside a categorization of existing research under this taxonomy, with emphasis placed on directions for future research oriented toward learning.

sec.title: The Problem: Attribute Overlap
sec.p: Early efforts at developing a taxonomy of game attributes yielded 39 different game elements (Garris & Ahlers, 2001). A follow-up study suggested that only 6 of these game attributes (fantasy, rules/goals, sensory stimuli, challenge, mystery, and control) were essential for learning based on the input-process-outcome game model (Garris, Ahlers, & Driskell, 2002). Wilson and colleagues (2009) expanded on this review by integrating game attributes with learning outcomes. They identified 18 game elements (see Table 1) as potentially leading to learning outcomes. This comprehensive list includes many of the attributes listed above, such as challenge and goals, alongside a variety of other attributes, including adaptation and mystery. In addition to compiling a comprehensive list of key game attributes, Wilson and colleagues attempted to link these attributes to specific learning outcomes (e.g., application, declarative knowledge, automaticity set) based on the experimental data from the various studies and articles they reviewed. The resulting 18 attributes are helpful when determining potential learning outcomes for games.

tr.td: Level of difficulty adjusts to the skill level of the player by matching challenges and possible solutions.

The measurement of achievement within game (e.g., scoring). Tutorials teach players how to play the game and what aspects are important to achieving the goals. Scoring compares performance among players. Feedback provides a tool for players to learn from previous actions and adjust accordingly.

Ideal amount of difficulty and improbability of obtaining goals. A challenging game possesses multiple clearly specified goals, progressive difficulty, and informational ambiguity. Challenge also adds fun and competition by creating barriers between current state and goal state.

The presentation of solvable problems within the game and usually drives the game’s plot or in-game action by providing interaction. Four types of conflict exist: (a) direct, (b) indirect, (c) violent, and (d) nonviolent.

The player’s capacity for power or influence over elements of the game. Learner control occurs when the learner has control over some aspects of the game. Instructional program control determines all elements of the game.

Make-believe environment, scenarios, or characters. It involves the player in mental imagery and imagination for unusual locations, social situations, and analogies for real-world processes. The player is also required to take on various roles in which they are expected to identify. Exogenous fantasy is a direct overlay on learning content. It is dependent on the skill, but the skill does not depend on the fantasy. Endogenous fantasy is related to learning content. It is an essential relationship between the learned skill and the fantasy context (engaging and educational).
The adaptability and manipulability of a game. The game changes in response to player’s actions.

Face-to-face interaction, relationships between players in real space and time. It provides an opportunity for achievements to be acknowledged by others, and challenges become meaningful, which induces involvement.
Interpersonal activity that is mediated by technology, which encourages entertaining communal gatherings by producing a sense of belonging.
Specific communication rules of the game, and may be a significant part of the game. The two types of communication are verbal and text.

The physical or virtual world that the game takes place in. It influences rules, expectations, and solution parameters. The location may be real or fantasy and the space may be bound, unbound, or augmented.

Gap between existing information and unknown information. It is a product of discrepancies or inconsistencies in knowledge. This attribute is enhanced by information incongruity, complexity, novelty, surprise and expectation violation, idea incompatibility, inability to make predictions, and incomplete or inconsistent information. Sensory curiosity is the interest evoked by novel sensations, and cognitive curiosity is the desire for knowledge related with curiosity (inverse quadratic).
Objects or people (e.g., proxy items, avatars, or human participants) being included in the game narrative or scenario.
How the player progresses toward the goals of the game.
The random elements of the game.
The player’s perceptions of the game’s reality. It is a subjective feature that makes the game appear psychologically real.
Narrowing the scope of representation provides focus for the player.

Rules are the goal makeup of game and establish criteria for how to win. Specific, well-defined rules and guidelines are a necessary component for an effective educational game, as well as feedback on progression toward achieving the goals. Three types of rules exist: (a) system rules (i.e., functional parameters inherent in the game), (b) procedural rules (i.e., actions in game to regulate behavior), and (c) imported rules (i.e., rules originating from real world).
Disassociation of actions and consequences (i.e., safe way to experience reality). The only consequence is loss of dignity when losing. The results are less harsh than modeled scenarios.
Visual or auditory stimulations, which distort perception and imply temporary acceptance of an alternate reality.

fn.p: Source: Adapted from Wilson et al., 2009.

sec.p: However, attempting to use this matrix to investigate relationships between game attributes and learning outcomes proves problematic, as these 18 items consist of overlapping attributes. For example, the game attribute “pieces and players” is defined as the objects or people who are included in the game scenario (Owen, 2004). If one wanted to determine whether pieces and players contribute to increased declarative knowledge, then it would seem plausible to

list-item.p: manipulate the nature of pieces and players
test different versions of the game using these manipulations
examine knowledge differences based on a measure of information gain

sec.p: A problem exists with this hypothetical experiment, given the attribute definitions outlined by Wilson and colleagues. The game attribute “representation” is defined as the game player’s perception of the level of reality within a game (Crawford, 1984). Changing the “pieces and players” attribute (e.g., adding realistic objects) could easily alter the player’s perception of the game’s reality (e.g., another planet, other than Earth). So using the examples provided, adding realistic objects to a planet other than Earth could influence the perception of reality as being “more real” even though the setting is completely unrealistic. If this were the case, it would be difficult to determine if the learning outcome of increased declarative knowledge was solely due to the intentional manipulation of “pieces and players” or the unintentional manipulation of the “representation” attribute. The overlap of criterion space makes research efforts aimed at mapping specific attributes to learning outcomes difficult.

This brings to light the chief concern of classifying or modifying game attributes: their interrelated nature. To provide links between learning outcomes and game attributes, controlled, laboratory experiments are a necessary first step. Yet, to proceed with such controlled research, the field requires a discrete taxonomy of game attributes that can be independently manipulated.

sec.title: Expert Mental Models
sec.p: Game attribute constructs must be as orthogonal as possible so that their unique contributions to outcomes of interest can be isolated. To this end, we found it imperative to move toward construct distinction by combining similar attributes (i.e., attributes that overlapped in experimental manipulations). This process required the development of an expert mental model regarding the specific crucial elements that constitute a game. Essentially, mental models are organized mental representations of knowledge (Mathieu, Heffner, Goodwin, Salas, & Cannon-Bowers, 2000). An expert mental model, then, is a mental model derived from knowledge representations of experts. By merging the models of multiple experts, it is possible to create a generic expert mental model. Thus, card sorting, an established technique for mental model elicitation, was chosen for this research.

sec.title: Card Sorting
sec.p: Card sorting is a frequently used categorization technique designed to investigate mental models (Nielsen & Sano, 1995). In a card sort, participants are provided with cards that have topics, words, or some other kind of information displayed on them. Participants sort these cards based on the relationships they perceive. One common card sort technique is the open card sort, wherein participants cluster cards based on their own idea of how each concept relates and then participants create names for all resulting groups (Fincher & Tenenberg, 2005). Upchurch, Rugg, and Kitchenham (2001) noted that card sorts were developed based on the notion of Kelly’s (2003) Personal Construct Theory, which states that individuals categorize the world differently based on their own unique interpretation. However, enough similarities in those unique categorizations exist that individuals are able to understand one another even though they possess different mental models for a situation or task.

Key differences exist between expert and novice mental models. Experts base model formation on semantic characteristics (e.g., task utility) rather than syntactic characteristics (e.g., alphabetical order; Fincher & Tenenberg, 2005). Novices do not necessarily use less organization in their models, but rather their categorizations are not based on complete domain knowledge. As a result, novices tend to show greater within-group variability in categorizations as compared with experts (Fincher & Tenenberg, 2005). Consequently, this card sort aimed to capture the expert mental model for the organization of these orthogonal gaming attributes, as the categorizations of experts were more salient to our research needs and, importantly, less subject to variability. This would allow us to arrive at consensus regarding game attributes that are actually considered relevant by those who work with games on a regular basis.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Based on these considerations, experienced game players (i.e., individuals who self-identified themselves as “gamers” rather than occasional or casual players of video games) and game developers were recruited as SMEs to aid in collapsing the original 18 game attributes identified by Wilson et al. (2009). In order to obtain this information from the SMEs, a card sort technique was employed using websort.net (an online card sort system). Based on preliminary feedback obtained from face-to-face discussions with two SMEs regarding the inherent disparity in the progress/surprise attribute originally outlined by Wilson and colleagues, it was split into individual attributes of progress and surprise (refer to Table 1 for complete list and a brief definition of all attributes). After this alteration to the list of learning-oriented game attributes, the card sort was seeded with the 19 attributes and corresponding definitions.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Given the unique demographics of the population of interest, participants were recruited using a variety of online gamer forums (e.g., The Escapist’s forum, the Penny Arcade forum), email lists (e.g., the Serious Games listserv), and internal circulation at video game development studios (e.g., Electronic Arts Tiburon branch, Popcap Games). Development studios, serious gaming list servers, and potentially interested individuals who were known to work with serious games or were known longtime players, received an email message containing information about the study, contact information for a researcher, Institutional Review Board (IRB) information, and a link to initiate the card sort and survey. Online postings provided the same information for serious gaming forums and concentrations of SMEs.

A total of 65 game players and game developers participated anonymously in the survey (after removing six participants due to invalid data—e.g., failure to sort cards, or sorting cards into one pile). Game players (n = 50) played video games regularly, averaging 17.77 hours per week, and had experience with a variety of game genres (e.g., first-person shooters, real-time strategy, role-playing, etc.). Game developers (n = 15) were professional or hobbyist programmers or designers of video games, who spent an average of 14.28 hours a week developing games. Participants ranged in age from 16 to 44 years (M = 24.27) with 90% of all respondents being male.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The list of items to be sorted was based on the literature review conducted by Wilson and colleagues (2009) augmented to comprise the 19 learning-oriented game attributes as described earlier (see Table 1). WebSort (via websort.net) was used to conduct an electronic card sort. The simple web-based interface that WebSort provides imposes minimal inconvenience to participants, as it allows them to perform a card sort using their web browser.

A posttask survey using the Unit Command Climate Assessment and Survey System (UCCASS) web survey system was also produced. The short six-item survey recorded participant age, gender, experience with gameplay and development, and which three gaming attributes the participant considered generally most important (see appendix).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Once participants accessed Websort.net, they entered a pseudonym to allow their card sort to be anonymously tied to their survey responses. After providing this pseudonym, participants saw a list of the 19 game attributes described in Table 1. Each game attribute was presented as part of a list on the left side of the screen. Participants sorted each attribute into participant-created folders or categories. Rather than providing predefined categories, an open card technique enabled the expertise of gamers and developers to create meaningful groupings. Participants sorted the cards based on their relatedness into categories of their own choosing.

After finishing the card sort, participants completed a postsort survey of demographic information and answered several questions about the game attributes. All questions were optional except for the pseudonym, in order to tie the card sort with the demographic data. Only two respondents did not fully complete the questionnaire, resulting in a 97% completion rate.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: No significant differences were found between game developer and game player responses to the card sort. The clustering data obtained from the participants provided groupings for the 19 original attributes into nine categories (see Table 2). The four primary clusters (distinguishable by the green, red, gold, and blue colors in Figure 1) obtained via cluster analysis of the card sort data were examined based on the lowest grouping branch relationships (e.g., interaction interpersonal grouped with interaction social) in order to provide categories based on the most consistently linked attributes. In the analysis of these clusters, two primary clusters contained elements that were, by definition, quite similar. As the goal of this effort was to create experimentally manipulatable categories, this was a potential issue. To avoid any problems in definition, local SMEs (i.e., game researchers and programmers who did not complete the card sort) distinguished cluster definitions. These SMEs had more programming experience than the least experienced participant had and were familiar with the game literature. These SMEs then considered each resulting pair in comparison with one another regarding the definitions of the component attributes (based on Wilson et al.) as well as any existing empirical findings to determine potential degrees of overlap. For example, if all attributes within two different categories had been shown to have similar relationships with a learning outcome, these could be considered overlapping and, thus, able to be merged. As a result of this process, the challenge-adaptation pair was merged with the conflict-surprise pair, as their relationship to immersion in a game was very similar (see Table 2). Finally, the safety and pieces or players attributes were not strongly linked with any other attributes. Based on further consultation with these SMEs, these orphaned attributes were subsequently merged with the related representation-sensory stimuli cluster in order to avoid continued construct overlap.

tr.td: A game that has textual commands that the player must type in order to convey their intent vs. a game that uses a gaming pad or joystick to interpret commands.

A game that shows a log of objectives to complete and scores based on individual actions at the end vs. a game that leaves the player in the dark during gameplay and gives a raw point score at completion.
A game that adapts the number of enemies faced or the power of those enemies based on how the player performs vs. a game that increases difficulty at a constant level.
A game that allows players to pick up any object and manipulate it, throw it, damage it, etc. vs. a game that only renders objects as static obstacles. The manipulations a player exerts on a game.
A game set in an office building vs. a game set in the jungles of Cambodia—the actual location where the game takes place.

A game set in a military operation would have generally consistent reality vs. a game set in a military operation where it is possible for orbital lasers and balloon-borne crossbow infantry to suddenly join in an ambush in Afghanistan would have a rather inconsistent fantasy reality.
A networked game that provides voice chat and has a supervisor giving support vs. a game that isolates the player from all other human contact.
Pieces or players, representation, sensory stimuli, safety

A game that uses movie-quality sound effects and force-feedback vibration to capture to shock and intensity of landing at the beach on WW2 Normandy vs. a game that uses blips and beeps to represent an oncoming low-fidelity space invader.

A game that makes it clear that the player must obtain three pieces of a key and combine them using their blowtorch, which can only be used for 2 minutes vs. a game that simply presents a locked door.

caption.p: Note: The ordering of the clusters (i.e., green cluster first, red cluster second, etc.) is based on the frequency of pairings made by the subject matter experts (SMEs). Thus, interaction interpersonal was linked with interaction social more often than representation was linked with sensory stimuli. However, it does not reflect the consistency of such pairings. That is reflected in the level at which attributes are linked. In other words, when representation was linked with another attribute, it was consistently sensory stimuli. Therefore, each of these attribute pairings (e.g., interaction interpersonal–interaction social and representation-sensory stimuli) are shown as linked within the fist level of cluster pairings.

sec.p: Although these modifications were post hoc, they must be considered in the context of the larger goal of a parsimonious, experimentally useful taxonomy of attributes. Without these changes, the taxonomy would be highly representative of an expert mental model of game attributes, but potentially fall prey to the same limitations as past organizations of game attributes (i.e., overlap and ambiguity with regard to research objectives). Our target population, while possessing appropriate game-relevant knowledge, lacks knowledge of experimental design. Therefore, as the purpose of this taxonomy is to provide an experimentally relevant and largely orthogonal set of attribute categories, these adjustments are preferable to using the clustering results without examining their implications.

Provided below are detailed descriptions of the adjusted resulting categories as well as the attributes that comprise each category. It is important to note that these attribute categories are defined by a number of factors and cannot generally be viewed as being “present” or “absent”—rather, they are persistent qualities instantiated in different ways. For clarity, the attribute categories are presented as proper nouns (i.e., capitalized), while the attributes that comprise these categories remain lowercase.

sec.title: Action Language
sec.p: The Action Language category consists of the attribute of language/communication. Distinct from human interaction, language/communication comprises the specific communication rules of the game (Owen, 2004). This communication is not between humans, but rather between a player and the system. The language of the game refers to the method by which players can make their intent clear to the system. For example, in a simple game, players may want to move their characters and pick up an object. However, because of the abstraction that is inherent to the game, this action would require pressing buttons within the controller interface (e.g., game pad, keyboard, mouse, etc.) such as a “forward” button and a “pick up” button. In some contemporary gaming systems using motion capture or a motion input device, such as the Nintendo Wii or even the Apple iPhone, this lexicon of actions approaches abstracted physical interaction, where all a player needs to do to accomplish a task is move the controller in a specific way that mimics forward movement and bending down to pick up the desired object. The Action Language of a game includes not only the method by which a user interacts with the system, but also the interface that allows them to do so. Because of this, both the interface and the method of interaction provide means by which to vary the Action Language of games (Harteveld, Guimarães, Mayer, & Bidarra, 2010).

sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: Assessment describes the nature and content of any feedback given to the player during the course of a game (e.g., debriefing, feedback, etc.). The Assessment category is composed of two attributes: assessment and progress. The attribute assessment is the measurement of achievement (e.g., scoring) within a game (Chen & Michael, 2005), and progress is how the player advances toward game goals (Owen, 2004). Such feedback provides information concerning the player’s performance and indicates what goals have yet to be completed. Furthermore, it can guide player action by providing subtle hints or overt instructions. Scoring/goal progress information can be presented throughout the progress of the game or after the game is completed. In games, the level of detail for this information can range from simple point displays to more complicated systems that track the total and partial completion of objectives (e.g., the “quest log” feature popular in massively multiplayer online role-playing games). The actual methods of assessment employed in games are the subject of considerable discussion in the literature (Salas, Rosen, Held, & Weissmuller, 2009). Regardless of the method by which the overarching category of Assessment is achieved, however, it is clear that Assessment is a key component of games given that feedback on gameplay is largely driven by an understanding of levels of achievement.

sec.title: Conflict/Challenge
sec.p: Conflict/Challenge refers to both the presentation of problems in a game as well as the nature and difficulty of such problems. The Conflict/Challenge category includes the adaptation, challenge, conflict, and surprise attributes. More specifically, the Conflict/ Challenge of a game refers to

list-item.p: the difficulty of the game (i.e., challenge)
the nature of the problems presented to players (i.e., conflict)
the degree of uncertainty inherent in the definition of these problems (i.e., surprise)

sec.p: While surprise and challenge are straightforward to conceptualize, conflict is somewhat more nebulous. Defining the nature of the conflict in a game can be accomplished via a number of dimensions, such as violent-nonviolent (Gentile & Gentile, 2008) or verbal-kinetic. The attribute of adaptation refers to the degree to which the game alters its difficulty based on player action. Ideally, the degree of challenge should automatically adapt according to the skill level of the player in order to engender optimum experience or flow state (i.e., a high-engagement, intrinsically satisfying experience; Csikszentmihalyi, 1990; Sweetser & Wyeth, 2005). As the source of the uncertainty of goal attainment, Conflict/Challenge provides the driving action behind the game. This category answers questions such as,

list-item.p: How does the game challenge the player?
Is challenge level adapted based on player performance or does it remain absolute?
Are additional conflicts and challenges introduced without the player’s foreknowledge, or are impending challenges announced in some way?

sec.title: Control
sec.p: Control refers to the degree of actual interaction and agency the player is capable of in a game. The attributes control and interaction (equipment) constitute the Control category. Control, as an attribute, is the amount of active learner control over content or gameplay and the player’s capacity for power or influence over elements of the game (Garris et al., 2002). Interaction (equipment) is the extent to which the game changes in response to player’s actions (Prensky, 2001). The notion of “equipment” interaction is somewhat misleading, as the definition offered by Prensky refers to interaction that is not necessarily bound to equipment per se (e.g., weather changing in response to player action). For example, a game like HALF LIFE 2 has very high control, provided through a powerful physics engine that allows for interaction with almost any object in the environment. Conversely, a game like DOOM has almost no control, as the player can only manipulate a very limited set of objects (i.e., shoot enemies or objects and open doors). In games that straddle the line between simulation and game, the focus on truly interactive equipment may provide an important avenue for learning, as in the case of military use of off-the-shelf games (Fong, 2006).

sec.title: Environment
sec.p: Environment comprises solely of the location attribute. It is defined as the representation of the physical surroundings in which the player is immersed (Owen, 2004). This category is best represented by questions such as (a) “Where is the player?” and (b) “How does the player view this world?” For example, the video game HALO is set in science fiction environments that not only situate the gameplay in a physical environment, but also serve to provide context for the game.

sec.title: Game Fiction
sec.p: Game Fiction describes the nature of the game world and story. This category consists of two attributes: fantasy and mystery. Fantasy refers to elements that are disparate from the real world (Garris et al., 2002; Owen, 2004), while mystery is the gap between known and unknown information (Garris et al., 2002). Game Fiction is the category that describes how the game’s world presents to the player. Therefore, when examining Game Fiction, it must be determined whether

list-item.p: the game world is realistic or fantastic
the player knows the nature of the world
the player’s actions and consequences are represented directly or indirectly

sec.p: For example, a history game’s fiction is likely to have low levels of fantasy if it models or references true events in a realistic fashion (Kee, 2011). In a game that harnesses mystery, informational complexity and incompleteness exist. In other words, in a game with mystery, the player should experience a gap between existing information and unknown information.

sec.title: Human Interaction
sec.p: Human Interaction, as the name suggests, deals with any human-to-human contact involved in a game. Human Interaction essentially refers to the degree of contact the player has with other human agents throughout the course of the game. It comprises two different types of interaction, formally known as interaction (interpersonal) and interaction (social). Interaction (interpersonal) describes the relationships between players in real space and time (e.g., face-to-face interaction; Crawford, 1984). Interpersonal interactions can include both interdependent and competitive actions. Interaction (social) is interpersonal activity mediated by technology (Prensky, 2001). For example, some games include technology-mediated interactions such as instant messenger communication or voice chat.

sec.title: Immersion
sec.p: Immersion describes the player’s perceptual and affective relationship with the Game Fiction. Immersion is embodied by the attributes of pieces/players, representation, sensory stimuli, and safety. Immersion is distinct from the concept of Game Fiction in that Immersion captures the player’s perception of their place within a game world (e.g., their judgment of its immediacy and salience), whereas Game Fiction describes the game world. In other words, Immersion focuses on the player’s perception and response to Game Fiction.

Immersion has a number of attributes that define this player response. One attribute is representation, the player’s perception of their self within the game’s reality (i.e., their perception of their relationship to the game world rather than the definition and makeup thereof; Crawford, 1984). The sensory stimuli attribute refers to the degree of dramatic or novel visual and auditory stimuli (Garris et al., 2002) and may imply temporary acceptance of an alternate reality (i.e., representation). Another attribute is pieces and players, which are the objects or people being included in the game narrative or scenario (Owen, 2004). Yet another attribute is safety, the disassociation of actions and consequences—the freedom to act without fearing real-world repercussions (Crawford, 1984). The removal of real-world consequences assists in the establishment of immersion, as it removes concerns for the real world (Csikszentmihalyi, 1990) and allows the player to focus on the game itself. Immersion, therefore, refers to the degree to which the player feels like an actual agent within the game world. Similarly, Immersion includes the acceptance of sensory stimuli and game assets as constituting something the player will accept as part of a contiguous system instead of disparate elements of an artificial game task. Unless carefully designed, game interaction can actually provide a hindrance to Immersion (Bizzocchi & Woodbury, 2003), as dissonant or distracting game elements (e.g., a frustrating or poorly designed interaction) may remind players of their actual real-world state of playing a game.

sec.title: Rules/Goals
sec.p: Rules/Goals is perhaps the simplest category to examine from a theoretical standpoint, as the card sort revealed that it was conceptualized as a single attribute. At the category level, Rules/Goals consist of the degree to which the game has clear rules, goals, and information on progress toward goals; in other words, it constitutes the goal makeup of the game (Blunt, 2007; Owen, 2004). The attribute of rules/goals describes the reasons for which the player interacts with the game world, and the impetus for their in-game actions. Furthermore, the rules and goals of a game determine the method by which a player can solve problems in the game. These rules do not need to be explicitly stated to the player, but can be conveyed via affordances. For example, the rules of SUPER MARIO BROS implicitly require that the player progress toward the right side of the screen, as returning past where the screen has scrolled is impossible.

sec.title: Game Matrix
sec.p: Armed with this taxonomy of factors, it is possible to classify existing research based on the combined attribute categories (see Tables 3 and 4). Drawing on the initial matrix proposed by Wilson and colleagues (2009), we reorganized the findings based on the results of the card sort. This revised matrix (Table 3) should serve as a guide for individuals seeking to find further theoretical and empirical information on a specific attribute category and its relationship to learning outcomes.

caption.p: Research Linking Game Attributes and Learning Outcomes

fn.p: Note: + = positive. − = negative. • = unspecified or undetermined relationship. * = theoretical article Superscript numbers correspond to sources presented in Table 4.

caption.p: Summary of Research Conducted Linking Game Attributes and Learning Outcomes

sec.p: The new categories derived from the card sort permits classifying research constructs semantically. An article that references fantasy and reality in games, for example, would be placed under Game Fiction. Obviously, articles do not reference the attribute categories explicitly; therefore, the meaning of a construct or attribute must be matched with its relevant attribute category.

Similar to the caveats suggested in the previous work by Wilson and colleagues (2009), we submit that validating the theoretical linkages defined by this research suggests direction for future research. However, the absence of support in this matrix does not necessarily indicate the absence of a relationship. Rather, it may suggest the lack of empirical research on this relationship or that theoretical discussion has yet to address the potential linkage. Therefore, this matrix can be used to not only examine existing evidence for the relationship between an attribute category and a learning outcome, but more importantly, identify gaps in the literature. Wilson and colleagues (2009) suggested the field consider the gaps identified in the original matrix outlined in their article. However, due to the overlapping nature of many of the attributes included in their analysis, specific examination of attributes was difficult. Using this revised matrix, researchers will be able to test links between attributes and outcomes that lack empirical support, and further the state of the science on game-based training.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As a result of the card sort process, a more parsimonious list of gaming attribute categories was derived from the initial feature set of 19 attributes. The nine categories of Action Language, Assessment, Conflict/Challenge, Control, Environment, Game Fiction, Human Interaction, Immersion, and Rules/Goals cover a wide range of potential game states and features. While these categories are able to describe a wide range of game features, they are still distinct enough to avoid significant conceptual overlap. Consequently, these categories allow manipulations to attributes in an experimental fashion in order to show direct links to learning outcomes. For example, a game’s Assessment can be altered without implications for its Environment, providing a useful avenue for controlled research.

One of the prime difficulties of serious games research on gaming attribute effects has been disentangling the measured effects of one attribute from the potential effects of other attributes. For example, past experiments manipulating fidelity in first-person shooter games have made the game behavior more realistic by changing levels of representation and sensory stimuli (Barlow & Morrison, 2005)—what would be called Immersion in our taxonomy. However, by modifying in-game avatars to behave realistically to suppressive fire, the researchers also inadvertently altered the level of the control the player has over their avatar. This entangling makes it difficult to determine exactly what alterations to the game system resulted in the changes measured by the experimenters. With a more rigidly defined series of attributes, drawing clear divisions between manipulations becomes much more feasible.

Of particular interest in the results is the isolation of the Rules/Goals attribute. Games can be effectively defined as leisure-oriented goal-based activities (Ang, 2006) as opposed to passive leisure, such as television, and it is interesting that the category established itself as a singular entity. It is easy to imagine a potential theoretical linkage between Assessment and Rules/Goals, but the distinction garnered from the card sort results indicates that the progress in a game and the game’s evaluation thereof should be considered separately from the rules defining a task or challenge. Because these results came from players and developers themselves, they capture the overall mental model of experienced gamers. Thus, it can be inferred that this audience may view games as primarily goal-oriented systems.

The development of these categories is imperative to the advancement of the field; without distinct and defined gaming attribute categories, the experimental manipulation of these attributes is problematic. Within the sea of unorganized attributes, overlap and conflict exists; for example, challenge and conflict may be difficult to extricate from one another. When these attributes are combined into a higher level construct, however, worry over whether modifying one will obfuscate the other as long as they comprise the same overall construct is mitigated. For example, if a researcher is interested in manipulating Game Fiction, fantasy and mystery can be manipulated at the same time with the knowledge that they are contributing to the overall construct of Game Fiction. Between categories, a potential for problematic interactions through unclear manipulation design still exists, such as alerting Immersion by broadly changing a variety of game elements, and inadvertently affecting Environment. However, this is a problem of poor planning rather than an issue with the taxonomy and, thus, best solved by careful experimental design of manipulations. In order to advance the goal of linking specific game attributes and learning outcomes, the ability to isolate constructs is critical to the revealing of links in attributes and outcomes.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Despite providing useful results that allowed for the creation of a new taxonomy of game attributes, the card sort process encountered some difficulties requiring further consideration. The card sort was online, which, therefore, presented an increased risk of participants performing the sort without fully understanding the directions. To rectify this issue, the data were examined before analysis in order to cull any invalid data. Some players sorted the entire list of items into just one category (i.e., not sorting at all), while others sorted into two categories (“good for games” vs. “bad for games”), and still others sorted the attributes into categories named after popular games to show examples of where the attributes fall in contemporary games. In each of these cases, the data provided were not useful to the goal of collapsing game attributes into categories. As this was a result of participants not reading or failing to understand the card sort directions, the data were deleted and the participant information removed from the demographic information, resulting in a total of six subjects removed. In addition, some attributes (i.e., pieces or players and safety) lacked consistent sorting with other elements, suggesting that the definitions provided for these attributes may not have been clear to participants.

We have some concern over the shifting of the two “orphaned” attributes that occurred after the initial card sort clustering. Unfortunately, the analysis of the emergent clusters resulted in some definitions that were still overlapping. In order to provide a useful set of definitions for game attributes, it was necessary to consult with SMEs for further resolution of the problematic clusters. In each of the two cases of shifting, the attribute moved was initially situated on its own branch, weakly linked to an adjacent cluster. To resolve potential ambiguity in the taxonomy, discussions between researchers and SMEs regarding each affected attribute definition occurred to determine the most appropriate cluster for the attribute.

Furthermore, the resulting categories are not entirely orthogonal. For instance, altering Game Fiction could result in a change in how the players interpret the environment. However, we argue that research manipulating one to determine the resulting impact on another attribute is necessary to continue to move this field forward. Yet, the resulting taxonomy is still valuable in that, without attempts to disentangle these attributes into more meaningful clusters, such research is not possible.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Considerable research in the serious games community focusing on cognitive and emotional spheres of inquiry exists; the study of motivation, emotion, attention, and many other psychological constructs occur within the context of games. With a refined taxonomy of games, research on game attributes and their effects on learning can progress in a purposeful and unified fashion. The game attribute categories proposed in this article are useful beyond the study of learning outcomes, to further an understanding of how game attributes work to create a whole game. In the effort to understand the relationship between games and learning, approaching the subject in a bottom-up, basic-science fashion by examining individual attribute-outcome links will allow for a distributed scientific discovery. The taxonomy derived from this effort provides researchers with an important tool from which to organize research efforts. Once examined, the identified attribute-outcome relationships can aid the scientific community in building an integrated model of learning in serious games and lead to mature efforts in game-based learning. We encourage the scientific community to continue investigation into the relationship between attributes and outcomes and hope this taxonomy and resulting matrix depicting the state of the science are useful. Such research will enable a future review, allowing for comparison of the current state of the science with future efforts.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Wendy L. Bedwell is a graduate research associate and doctoral candidate in the Industrial/Organizational Psychology program at the University of Central Florida (UCF). Her research focuses on enhancing adaptive collaborative performance through training. Ms. Bedwell’s emphasis is twofold: (a) enhancing training effectiveness by linking training characteristics to learning outcomes and (b) understanding the effects of membership fluidity on adaptive collaborative performance in teams. Contact: wbedwell@ist.ucf.edu

Davin Pavlas is a graduate of the Applied Experimental and Human Factors doctoral program at UCF. He obtained his PhD in 2010 through a dissertation examining flow, play, and learning. Currently, he is the user researcher at Riot Games. Contact: davin@pavlas.com

Kyle Heyne is a casual gamer and games researcher. He has completed his master’s in modeling and simulation from UCF and is currently pursuing a doctorate in applied experimental and human factors psychology from the same university. His research interests center on communication in teams, especially as applied to medical teams. Contact: kheyne@ist.ucf.edu

Elizabeth H. Lazzara received her degree in psychology from the University of South Florida in 2005. She is a graduate research associate and doctoral candidate within the Applied Experimental Human Factors program, Institute for Simulation and Training, UCF, where her research interests include team training, simulation-based training, and performance measurement, with an emphasis in health care. Contact: elazzara@ist.ucf.edu

Eduardo Salas is trustee chair and professor of psychology at UCF. In this position and his previous role as head of the Training Technology Development Branch of Naval Air Farware Center Training Systems Division (NAWC-TSD), he has served as a principal investigator for numerous R&D programs, authored or coauthored more than 450 journal articles and book chapters, and coedited 25 books on teamwork, training, and measurement. Contact: esalas@ist.ucf.edu
